For example, although only circular, triangular, and square hollow metal conduits are explicitly discussed, one of skill in the art would realize that virtually any hollow fluid conduit could be substituted. The microbiological species listed herein are intended to provide a sample of the potential microbiological species that can be supported in a fermentor or fermentor system as described herein.
The disclosure of U.S. provisional patent application Ser. No. 61/711,104, filed Oct. 8, 2012, is incorporated herein in its entirety.

The various embodiments described above can be combined to provide further embodiments. All of the U.S. patents, U.S. patent application publications, U.S. patent applications, foreign patents, foreign patent applications and non-patent publications referred to in this specification and/or listed in the Application Data Sheet, including but not limited to: U.S. Provisional Patent Application Ser. No. 61/671,542, filed Jul. 13, 2012; is incorporated herein by reference, in their entirety. Aspects of the embodiments can be modified, if necessary, to employ systems, processes, biological media, and concepts of the various patents, applications and publications to provide yet further embodiments.

These and other changes can be made to the embodiments in light of the above-detailed description. In general, in the following claims, the terms used should not be construed to limit the claims to the specific embodiments disclosed in the specification and the claims, but should be construed to include all possible embodiments along with the full scope of equivalents to which such claims are entitled. Accordingly, the claims are not limited by the disclosure.

claim.claim-text: 1. A system to stimulate biological growth, the system comprising: at least one hollow fluid conduit disposed within an interior space formed by a vessel, the at least one hollow fluid conduit permitting a fluid flow therethrough, the at least one fluid conduit including at least one inlet and at least one outlet;wherein the inlet of the at least one hollow fluid conduit is in fluid communication with the interior space of the vessel to provide a downward flow path bordered by an external perimeter of the at least one hollow fluid conduit and by an internal perimeter of the vessel and an upward flow path bordered by an internal perimeter of the at least one hollow fluid conduit;at least one gas distributor disposed in the downward flow path to introduce one or more gases in at least a portion of the downward flow path;at least one first fluid mover to provide a downward fluid flow in the downward flow path and an upward fluid flow in the upward flow path; anda thermal transfer system thermally coupled to at least one of the downward flow path or the upward flow path.

2. The system of claim 1 wherein the at least one fluid mover is disposed at least partially in the downward flow path and fluidly coupled to the at least one hollow fluid conduit inlet to induce a fluid flow in the downward flow path and to force a fluid flow in the upward flow path.

3. The system of claim 1 wherein the at least one fluid mover is disposed external to both the upward flow path and the downward flow path, and is fluidly coupled to the downward flow path to force a fluid flow in both the upward flow path and the downward flow path.

4. The system of claim 1 wherein the at least one fluid mover is disposed external to both the upward flow path and the downward flow path, and is fluidly coupled to the upward flow path to induce a fluid flow in both the upward flow path and the downward flow path.

5. The system of claim 1 wherein the thermal transfer system thermally coupled to at least one of the downward flow path or the upward flow path comprises a thermal transfer system thermally conductively coupled to at least a portion of the at least one fluid conduit.

6. The system of claim 1 wherein the thermal transfer system thermally coupled to at least one of the downward flow path or the upward flow path comprises a thermal transfer system thermally conductively coupled to at least a portion of the vessel.
7. The system of claim 1 wherein the vessel further comprises a biomass accumulator to encourage an accumulation of excess biomass in at least a portion of the interior space formed by the vessel.

8. The system of claim 7 wherein the biomass accumulator includes sloping or curving at least a portion of the vessel to encourage the accumulation of excess biomass in at least a portion of the interior space formed by the vessel.
9. The system of claim 7 wherein the vessel further comprises a connection proximate the biomass accumulator to facilitate the removal of excess biomass from the biomass accumulator.
10. The system of claim 1 wherein at least a portion of the upward flow path includes one or more structures to promote biomass growth.

11. The system of claim 1 wherein at least a portion of the upward flow path includes one or more structures promoting mass transfer between phases of a multi-phase fluid flowing in the at least one fluid conduit.
12. The system of claim 1 wherein at least a portion of the downward flow path includes one or more structures to promote biomass growth.

13. The system of claim 1 wherein at least a portion of the downward flow path includes one or more structures promoting mass transfer between phases of a multi-phase fluid flowing in the at least one fluid conduit.

14. The system of claim 1 further comprising at least one separator to promote the separation of a multi-phase fluid into a plurality of phases, the separator fluidly coupled to receive at least a portion of the multi-phase fluid from the at least one hollow fluid conduit outlet.
15. The system of claim 14 wherein a total internal volume of the at least one separator is at least 10% of a total internal volume of the vessel.
16. The system of claim 14 wherein the separator is further fluidly coupled to the vessel to return at least a portion of the separated multi-phase fluid to the downward flow path.
17. The system of claim 14, further comprising a vacuum generator operably coupled to the separator to produce a reduced pressure therein.
18. The system of claim 1 further comprising at least one backpressure generator fluidly coupled to the outlet of the at least one hollow fluid conduit.
19. The system of claim 18 wherein at least a portion of the at least one backpressure generators include one or more energy recovery systems.
20. The system of claim 19 wherein at least a portion of the one or more energy recovery systems includes a turbine operated electrical generator.

21. The system of claim 18 further comprising at least one separator to promote the separation of a multi-phase fluid into a plurality of phases, the separator fluidly coupled to receive at least a portion of the multi-phase fluid from the at least one backpressure generator.
22. The system of claim 21 wherein the separator is further fluidly coupled to the vessel to return at least a portion of the separated multi-phase fluid to the downward flow path.

23. The system of claim 1 wherein the at least one hollow fluid conduit includes a single hollow fluid conduit having a longitudinal axis oriented substantially parallel to a longitudinal axis of the vessel.
24. The system of claim 23 wherein the longitudinal axis of the single hollow fluid conduit is coaxially aligned with the longitudinal axis of the vessel.

25. The system of claim 1 wherein the at least one hollow fluid conduit includes a plurality of hollow fluid conduits, each having a respective longitudinal axis that is oriented substantially parallel to a longitudinal axis of the vessel.

26. The system of claim 25 wherein the respective longitudinal axis of each of the plurality of hollow fluid conduits are oriented substantially parallel to the longitudinal axes of all other hollow fluid conduits.
27. The system of claim 26 wherein the longitudinal axis of one of the plurality of hollow fluid conduits is coaxially aligned with the longitudinal axis of the vessel.
28. The system of claim 1 wherein the thermal transfer system includes a reservoir containing one or more heat transfer media thermally coupled to at least a portion of the vessel.

29. The system of claim 1 wherein at least one thermal transfer system includes a reservoir containing one or more heat transfer media thermally coupled to at least a portion of the at least one hollow fluid conduit.

30. The system of claim 1 wherein an aggregate total transverse cross sectional area of the at least one hollow fluid conduit is at least 10% of the total transverse cross sectional area of the vessel.

31. A method to stimulate biological growth, the method comprising: dispersing a gas in a liquid media including at least water and one or more nutrients to form a multi-phase mixture comprising gas bubbles dispersed in the liquid media;flowing at a first velocity and a first pressure the multi-phase mixture in one or more downward flow paths, the one or more downward flow paths formed between an exterior perimeter of a number of hollow fluid conduits and an interior perimeter of a vessel at least partially surrounding the number of hollow fluid conduits;increasing the pressure of the multi-phase mixture from the first pressure to a second pressure to produce compressed gas bubbles in the multi-phase mixture while contacting the multi-phase mixture with a number of microorganisms existent in the downward flow path to provide a first biomass; andflowing at a second velocity the multi-phase mixture in a number of upward flow paths, each of the respective number of upward flow paths formed by an interior perimeter of each of the number of hollow fluid conduits and maintaining the pressure at or above a third pressure to maintain compressed gas bubbles in the multi-phase mixture while contacting the multi-phase mixture with a number microorganisms existent in the upward flow path to provide a second biomass.
32. The method of claim 31, further comprising: maintaining a first temperature in the downward flow path using a thermal transfer system thermally coupled to the downward flow path.
33. The method of claim 31, further comprising: maintaining a second temperature in the upward flow path using a thermal transfer system thermally coupled to the upward flow path.
34. The method of claim 31 wherein the first velocity exceeds the rise rate of any gas bubbles present in the multi-phase fluid present in the downward flow path.
35. The method of claim 31 wherein the gas includes at least one carbon containing compound.
36. The method of claim 35 wherein the gas includes at least one hydrocarbon.
37. The method of claim 35, wherein the at least one carbon containing compound includes a carbon compound having at least a single carbon atom and at least a single oxygen atom.
38. The method of claim 35 wherein the gas includes at least one of hydrogen or a hydrogen containing compound.
39. The method of claim 36 wherein the gaseous substrate includes at least one of oxygen or an oxygen containing compound.
40. The method of claim 31 wherein the gas includes at least one of oxygen or an oxygen containing compound.
41. The method of claim 31 wherein the gas includes at least methane and oxygen.
42. The method of claim 41 wherein the methane feed rate is at least about 5 grams of methane per liter of liquid media (g/e).
43. The method of claim 41 wherein the oxygen feed rate is at least about 5 grams of oxygen per liter of liquid media (g/e).
44. The method of claim 31 wherein the gas is at a pressure of about 50 psi or more prior to dispersion in the liquid media.
45. The method of claim 31 wherein the gas is at a pressure of about 25 psi above the pressure of the liquid media prior to dispersion in the liquid media.

46. The method of claim 31, wherein dispersing a gas in a liquid media including at least water and one or more nutrients to form a multi-phase mixture comprising gas bubbles dispersed in the liquid media, includes: controlling the flow of the gas to maintain a dissolved oxygen concentration of less than about 10 ppm in the multi-phase mixture in the one or more downward flow paths.

47. The method of claim 31, wherein dispersing a gas in a liquid media including at least water and one or more nutrients to form a multi-phase mixture comprising gas bubbles dispersed in the liquid media, includes: controlling the flow of the gas to maintain a dissolved oxygen concentration of less than about 10 ppm in the multi-phase mixture in the one or more upward flow paths.

48. The method of claim 31, wherein dispersing a gas in a liquid media including at least water and one or more nutrients to form a multi-phase mixture comprising gas bubbles dispersed in the liquid media, includes: controlling the flow of the gas to maintain a dissolved methane concentration of less than about 5 ppm in the multi-phase mixture in the one or more downward flow paths.

49. The method of claim 31, wherein dispersing a gas in a liquid media including at least water and one or more nutrients to form a multi-phase mixture comprising gas bubbles dispersed in the liquid media, includes: controlling the flow of the gas to maintain a dissolved methane concentration of less than about 5 ppm in the multi-phase mixture in the one or more upward flow paths.

50. The method of claim 31, further comprising: separating the multi-phase mixture removed from the one or more upward flow paths into a plurality of phases including at least a separated gas phase and a separated liquid phase.

51. The method of claim 50, further comprising: reducing the pressure of the multi-phase mixture removed from the one or more upward flow paths to a fourth pressure prior to separating the multi-phase mixture.

52. The method of claim 51, further comprising: generating electricity by at least partially reducing the pressure of the multi-phase mixture to a fourth pressure using one or more energy capture systems.
53. The method of claim 50 wherein the separated liquid phase includes at least one C2 or higher hydrocarbon.

54. The method of claim 53 wherein the at least one C2 or higher hydrocarbon includes at least one of: one or more glycols, one or more ketones, one or more alcohols, one or more C4 hydrocarbons or compounds thereof, one or more C5 hydrocarbons or compounds thereof, or one or more C6 hydrocarbons or compounds thereof.
55. The method of claim 51 wherein the separated liquid phase includes a biomass comprising at least one lipid useful in the production of one or more biofuels.
56. The method of claim 51 wherein the separated gas phase comprises at least one C2 or higher hydrocarbon.
57. The method of claim 56 wherein the at least one C2 or higher hydrocarbon includes at least one of: ethane or compounds thereof, ethylene, propane, propylene, butane, butene.
58. The method of claim 31 wherein the first velocity comprises a superficial fluid velocity of greater than about 0.1 feet per second (f/s).
59. The method of claim 31 wherein the first pressure comprises a pressure of from about 5 pounds per square inch gauge (psig) to about 100 psig.
60. The method of claim 31 wherein the second pressure comprises a pressure of from about 5 pounds per square inch gauge (psig) to about 150 psig.
61. The method of claim 31 wherein the third pressure comprises a pressure of from about 5 pounds per square inch gauge (psig) to about 100 psig.
62. The method of claim 31 wherein the second velocity comprises a bulk fluid velocity of less than about 10 feet per second (f/s).
63. The method of claim 31 wherein the first biomass includes at least one of: one or more methanotrophs or one or more methylotrophs.

64. The method of claim 31 wherein the first biomass includes one or more of the following species: Methylomonas, Methylobacter, Methylococcus, Methylosinus, Methylocystis, Methylomicrobium, Methanomonas, Methylophilus, Methylobacillus, Methylobacterium, Hyphomicrobium, Xanthobacter, Bacillus, Paracoccus, Nocardia, Arthrobacter, Rhodopseudomonas, Pseudomonas, Clostridium, Moorella, Pyrococcus, Eubacterium, Desulfobacterium, Carboxydothermus, Acetogenium, Acetobacterium, Acetoanaerobium, Butyribaceterium, Peptostreptococcus, Candida, Yarrowia, Hansenula, Pichia, Torulopsis, and Rhodotorula

65. The method of claim 63 wherein the one or more methanotrophs include at least one of: Methylomonas sp. 16a (ATCC PTA 2402), Methylosinus trichosporium (NRRL B-II, 196), Methylosinus sporium (NRRL 20 B-II, 197), Methylocystis parvus (NRRL B-II, 198), Methylomonas methanica (NRRL B-11, 199), Methylomonas albus (NRRL B-II, 200), Methylobacter capsulatus (NRRL B-11, 201), Methylobacterium organophilum (ATCC 27,886), Methylomonas sp. AJ-3670 (FERM P-2400), Methylomicrobium alcaliphilum, Methylocella silvestris, Methylacidiphilum infernorum, Methylibium petroleiphilum, Methylosinus trichosporium 25 OB3b, Methylococcus capsulatus Bath, Methylomonas sp. 16a, Methylomicrobium alcaliphilum 20Z, or a high growth variants thereof.

66. The method of claim 63 wherein the one or more methylotrophs include at least one of: Methylobacterium extorquens, Methylobacterium radiotolerans, Methylobacterium populi, Methylobacterium chloromethanicum, Methylobacterium nodulans, Clostridium autoethanogenum, Clostridium ljungdahli, Clostridium ragsdalei, Clostridium carboxydivorans, Butyribacterium methylotrophicum, and Clostridium woodii, Clostridium neopropanologen.
67. The method of claim 31 wherein the second biomass includes at least one of: one or more methanotrophs or one or more methylotrophs.

68. The method of claim 31 wherein the second biomass includes one or more of the following species: Methylomonas, Methylobacter, Methylococcus, Methylosinus, Methylocystis, Methylomicrobium, Methanomonas, Methylophilus, Methylobacillus, Methylobacterium, Hyphomicrobium, Xanthobacter, Bacillus, Paracoccus, Nocardia, Arthrobacter, Rhodopseudomonas, Pseudomonas, Clostridium, Moorella, Pyrococcus, Eubacterium, Desulfobacterium, Carboxydothermus, Acetogenium, Acetobacterium, Acetoanaerobium, Butyribaceterium, Peptostreptococcus, Candida, Yarrowia, Hansenula, Pichia, Torulopsis, and Rhodotorula

69. The method of claim 67 wherein the one or more methanotrophs include at least one of: Methylomonas sp. 16a (ATCC PTA 2402), Methylosinus trichosporium (NRRL B-II, 196), Methylosinus sporium (NRRL 20 B-II, 197), Methylocystis parvus (NRRL B-II, 198), Methylomonas methanica (NRRL B-11, 199), Methylomonas albus (NRRL B-II, 200), Methylobacter capsulatus (NRRL B-11, 201), Methylobacterium organophilum (ATCC 27,886), Methylomonas sp. AJ-3670 (FERM P-2400), Methylomicrobium alcaliphilum, Methylocella silvestris, Methylacidiphilum infernorum, Methylibium petroleiphilum, Methylosinus trichosporium 25 OB3b, Methylococcus capsulatus Bath, Methylomonas sp. 16a, Methylomicrobium alcaliphilum 20Z, or a high growth variants thereof.

70. The method of claim 67 wherein the one or more methylotrophs include at least one of: Methylobacterium extorquens, Methylobacterium radiotolerans, Methylobacterium populi, Methylobacterium chloromethanicum, Methylobacterium nodulans, Clostridium autoethanogenum, Clostridium ljungdahli, Clostridium ragsdalei, Clostridium carboxydivorans, Butyribacterium methylotrophicum, and Clostridium woodii, Clostridium neopropanologen.
71. The method of claim 31, wherein at least one of the first biomass or the second biomass includes a heterologous methanotropic bacterium.
72. The method of claim 31, wherein at least one of the first biomass or the second biomass includes a syngas metabolizing bacterium.
73. The method of claim 31 wherein at least one of the first biomass or the second biomass includes a non-photosynthetic C1 metabolizing microorganism.
74. The method of claim 73 wherein the non-photosynthetic C1 metabolizing bacterium is an obligate C1 metabolizing non-photosynthetic microorganism.
75. The method of claim 31 wherein the C1 metabolizing non-photosynthetic microorganism is a recombinant C1 metabolizing non-photosynthetic microorganism comprising a heterologous polynucleotide.

76. The method of claim 75 wherein the recombinant C1 metabolizing non-photosynthetic microorganism comprising a heterologous polynucleotide produces one or more of the products propylene, propylene oxide, ethylene glycol, n-butanol, isobutanol, 1,3-butanediol, 1,4-butanediol, 2,3-butanediol, 3-hydroxypropionic acid or a salts thereof, or crotonic acid or salts thereof.

77. The method of claim 31 wherein the C1 metabolizing non-photosynthetic microorganism is a methanotroph, the C1 gas substrate includes methane, and the methanotrophs are cultured in an aerobic condition.

78. The method of claim 31 wherein the C1 metabolizing non-photosynthetic microorganism is a methanotroph, the C1 gas substrate includes methane, and the methanotrophs are cultured with limiting quantities of phosphorus, nitrogen, trace elements, oxygen, or any combination thereof.

79. The method of claim 31 wherein the CI metabolizing bacteria is a recombinant CI bacteria comprising a heterologous polynucleotide encoding a fatty acid producing enzyme, a formaldehyde assimilation enzyme, or a combination thereof.

80. An apparatus to stimulate biological growth, the apparatus comprising: a number of hollow fluid conduits disposed at least partially within a vertically arranged vessel to provide a number of downward flow paths bordered by an exterior perimeter of each of the number hollow fluid conduits and an interior perimeter of the vertically arranged vessel;wherein the vertically arranged vessel includes at least one fluid inlet connection fluidly coupled to at least a portion of the number of downward flow paths;wherein each of the number of hollow fluid conduits provides a respective number of upward flow paths, each of the upward flow paths bordered by an interior perimeter of each of the respective hollow fluid conduits, each of the number of upward flow paths fluidly coupled to at least connection to remove a multi-phase fluid;at least one gas distributor disposed in at least a portion of the number of downward flow paths; anda number of first structures disposed within at least a portion of at least one of: the number of downward flow paths or the upward flow paths, each of the number of first structures to promote biological growth thereupon.
81. The apparatus of claim 80, further comprising at least one first thermal transfer surface disposed at least partially in the number of downward flow paths.
82. The apparatus of claim 81 wherein the first thermal transfer surfaces comprise a thermal fluid reservoir disposed at least partially in the number of downward flow paths.
83. The apparatus of claim 80, further comprising one or more second thermal transfer surfaces disposed at least partially in at least a portion of the upward flow paths.
84. The apparatus of claim 83 wherein the second thermal transfer surfaces comprise a thermal fluid reservoir disposed at least partially in at least a portion of the upward flow paths.

85. The apparatus of claim 80 wherein the one or more gas distributors include: a first gas distributor fluidly coupled to at least one first gas inlet connection, the at least one first gas inlet connection to receive at least one carbon containing gas.

86. The apparatus of claim 85 wherein the one or more gas distributors include: a second gas distributor fluidly coupled to at least one second gas inlet connection, the at least one second gas inlet connection to receive at least one oxygen containing gas.
87. The apparatus of claim 80 wherein the at least one fluid inlet connection includes: at least one fluid connection to accept a fluid media including at least water.
88. The apparatus of claim 87 wherein the at least one fluid inlet connection further includes: at least one fluid connection to accept a fluid media including at least one biological nutrient.
89. The apparatus of claim 80 wherein an aggregate transverse cross-sectional area of the number of hollow fluid conduits is at least 10% of the transverse cross-sectional area of the vessel.
